ElementDef.EDComments: The <Jref\> element is used to create references to Clause and Schedules only. The value inside a <Jref\> is the filename (or Hard Reference) of the target document. <Jref\> elements are resolved into the appropriate values at various stages in the drafting process.

ElementDef.EDComments: The <Origin\> element is used in predominantly consolidated Bills. These are Bills which are made up of a number of other Bills (i.e. they are consolidated). The original source is referenced in the <Origin\> element. The origins are then used to construct the tables of origins and destinations using the AutoTables plugins.

ElementDef.EDComments: This element was called <InternalReference\> in Release 33 and below. It was changed to <Xref\> as it was becoming more widely used to create cross references between files.
This element is used to create cross references to <Chapter\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

The <DummyXref\> element is used within House amendments to indicate where a cross reference would be required when it is introduced into the Bill text. It is not intended for use within Bill text only.
This element is used to create cross references to <Part\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

\xd2 Abolition of defence of marital coercion
The defence of marital coercion is abolished.
Accordingly, section 47 of the Criminal Justice Act 1925 (coercion of
married woman by husband) is repealed.
This section does not have effect in respect of an offence alleged to have
been committed before the date on which it comes into force.\xd3

In subsection (2)(a), \xd2 the relevant period\xd3 means the period of 3

The second condition is that the officer has reasonable grounds
for believing that the making of a closure order under section
136D is necessary to prevent the premises being used for
activities related to one or more specified child sex offences.
For the purposes of the second condition, it does not matter

question have been committed or that they will be committed (or

If the local authority has not been consulted when the notice is

An authorisation under subsection (1) may be given orally or in
writing, but if it is given orally the authorising officer must
confirm it in writing as soon as it is practicable.
The issue of a closure notice may be authorised whether or not a
person has been convicted of any specified child sex offence that
the authorising officer believes has been committed.
The Secretary of State may by regulations specify premises or
descriptions of premises to which this section does not apply.\xd3
